Dr. Wendell R. Garner, professor of psychology at Johns Hopkins, has been awarded a distinguished scientific contribution

American Psychological Association for his experiments in psychophysics, discrimination, perception and learning.
The award was made at the
association's annual convention
in Los Angeles last weekend.

dealing with data.

and Structure as Psychological
Concepts," established a new
area of research in the study of
perception and learning, according to a university spokesman.

Free Is Not Easy
There is some sort of new freedom for every student
at the Homewood this year. While we upperclassmen
have merely been liberated.from last year's kink in the
great chain of time, you freshmen are beginning a new
life marked by a greater degree of autonomy than you
have previously known.
The administration has informed you, through
literature and orientation, of its official attitude: you are
assumed to be a young gentleman, mature beyond your
years, as responsible as the Honor Commission and as
honest as the semester is long. You are not.
You probably have a variable quantity of each
quality. The administration counts on this in its actual
attitude, which replaces the official words of hope with a
stoic gaze or silent acknowledgement.
You will soon find yourself to he ensconced among
similar contradictions. Most of these contradictions arise
from the opposition between ideals and practical realities. One is said to determine his own conduct according
to the dictates of his conscience as an individual, and
each man is supposed to be the safeguard of his own
honor, whereas all are automatically committed by enrollment to observe an honor code fabricated and installed here long ago.
One is said to govern himself in this community
of gentlemen through the various organs of "student
government," hut is certain to find these agencies inactive or ineffectual and non-representative because of
general apathy toward the idea of student initiative and
toward the petty concerns of adolescent politicians.
More disappointing yet will be the realization that all
such privileges of undergraduate self-determination are
extended because of their functional advantages to the
administration, if not because of the blind hope this
university has for its students.
The answer, of course, does not lie in the cynicism
one may be too quick to accuse this column of, but in
aspiration on the part of each student to carry these distasteful realities closer to those delicious ideals that fill
our atmosphere at the Homewood. Learn now to act as
though you deserve the hope, and perhaps even the tentative faith, on which Hopkins would like to be realistically based.
A freshman class which understands its position
'between the earth and the stars might begin a real tradition to justify the fiction of our old ideals. Study and
learn, most certainly, but think and act. Figure out what
is real and what is illusion here, and you will have true
freedom.

Free Is Not Easy
There is some sort of new freedom for every student
at the Homewood this year. While we upperclassmen
have merely been liberated.from last year's kink in the
great chain of time, you freshmen are beginning a new
life marked by a greater degree of autonomy than you
have previously known.
The administration has informed you, through
literature and orientation, of its official attitude: you are
assumed to be a young gentleman, mature beyond your
years, as responsible as the Honor Commission and as
honest as the semester is long. You are not.
You probably have a variable quantity of each
quality. The administration counts on this in its actual
attitude, which replaces the official words of hope with a
stoic gaze or silent acknowledgement.
You will soon find yourself to he ensconced among
similar contradictions. Most of these contradictions arise
from the opposition between ideals and practical realities. One is said to determine his own conduct according
to the dictates of his conscience as an individual, and
each man is supposed to be the safeguard of his own
honor, whereas all are automatically committed by enrollment to observe an honor code fabricated and installed here long ago.
One is said to govern himself in this community
of gentlemen through the various organs of "student
government," hut is certain to find these agencies inactive or ineffectual and non-representative because of
general apathy toward the idea of student initiative and
toward the petty concerns of adolescent politicians.
More disappointing yet will be the realization that all
such privileges of undergraduate self-determination are
extended because of their functional advantages to the
administration, if not because of the blind hope this
university has for its students.
The answer, of course, does not lie in the cynicism
one may be too quick to accuse this column of, but in
aspiration on the part of each student to carry these distasteful realities closer to those delicious ideals that fill
our atmosphere at the Homewood. Learn now to act as
though you deserve the hope, and perhaps even the tentative faith, on which Hopkins would like to be realistically based.
A freshman class which understands its position
'between the earth and the stars might begin a real tradition to justify the fiction of our old ideals. Study and
learn, most certainly, but think and act. Figure out what
is real and what is illusion here, and you will have true
freedom.

1964-65.

and James Bowman, must be given their due. We congratulate Strider for his promotion to Assistant Dean of
